results.title: The Living city
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Twentieth Century Fund and John Barnes
results.brief_description: Surveys the need for redevelopment of American cities and the forces which have created problems in urban areas; describes obstacles which deter the elimination of blighted areas and tenements and the relief of traffic congestion. Includes scenes of St Louis in 1890, and of present-day housing and building programs in Baltimore, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.

results.title: The Living cell: an introduction
results.brief_description: Introduces the fundamental principles of cell biology, examining structures and biochemical processes that occur in all living cells. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Living camera, with Paul
results.creator_credit: Time-Life Broadcast, Drew Associates, Robert Drew, Greg Shuker, R. Leacock and D.A. Pennebaker
results.brief_description: Can a murderer become rehabilitated while he sits in death row for nine years awaiting electrocution? If he can, should his sentence be commuted to life? A young Chicago attorney answers “yes” to both questions. He then undergoes the agony and elation of a successful plea to the parole board with famed Louis Nizer at his side. Filmed with hand-held camera and sound recorder.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Time-Life Broadcast, Drew Associates, Robert Drew, Greg Shuker, R. Leacock and D.A. Pennebaker

results.title: The Living bird
results.brief_description: The bird as a living creature. Its power of flight, structure, metabolism, senses of sight, smell and hearing. Remarkable scenes show bird courtship, nesting and the hatching of eggs of both altricial and precocious types.

results.title: The Lively art of picture books (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios and Joanna Foster
results.brief_description: Discusses the creation of picture books for children through interviews with artists Robert McCloskey, Barbara Cooney and Maurice Sendak. Shows examples of kinds of pictures used, various interpretations of the same subjects, and three complete picture books.

results.title: The Littlest rebel (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, B.G. De Sylva and David Butler
results.brief_description: The troubles of the Civil War come home to a little plantation girl when her father is arrested and charged with espionage against the Yankees. Only a plea to President Lincoln can save the day. One of the most dramatically interesting of Shirley Temple’s films, “The Littlest Rebel” is also a spirited musical comedy featuring an exuberant performance by the gifted dancer, Bill “Bojangles” Robinson.

results.title: The Littlest angel
results.brief_description: From the story by American children’s author, Charles Tazewell. A series of animated sketches are used to illustrate the well-known story of the littlest angel in Paradise who gave a simple wooden box containing a stone, a dog-collar and a pressed butterfly as his offering to celebrate the birth of the Christ-child. His gift is transformed by God into the Star of Bethlehem.

results.title: The Littlest ambassador
results.brief_description: The story of Rene Simard, aged 13, who visits Japan as a French-Canadian pop singer. Commentary paraphrases his spoken impressions and replies to questions. Includes scenes from the 3rd Tokyo Music Festival where Rene represents Canada and finally wins grand prize. Cameos by Frank Sinatra and Shirley Bassey.

results.title: The Little vampire
results.creator_credit: Vampire Productions, Richard Klaus and Uli Edel
results.brief_description: An only child receives a change of lifestyle when his father builds a golf course at the place where it all started, Scotland. Young Tony (Jonathan Lipnicki) is bullied at school, has a recurring dream about vampires and is miserable and without friends. His dreams prove founded when he is visited by a young boy from his dreams who turns out to be a vampire. Weak and unable to fly, Rudolph is taken care of by Tony who cares for the ailing bloodsucker and the two become friends. Tony educates Rudolph (Rollo Weeks) in the mores of life in the 21st century and Rudolph shares his life story - his family, the Sackville-Baggs are part of a vampire community cursed as lost souls until a powerful amulet can be restored to lift the curse. Tony joins the quest, even though it will mean losing the circle of friends he has found in the process. Based on the novels by Angela Sommer-Bodenburg. Cast also includes Richard E Grant, Jim Carter, Alice Krige and Anna Popplewell.

results.title: The Little theme
results.creator_credit: Zanthus Films, Unifed Film Foundation and Anne Graham
results.brief_description: A sensitive presentation of variations on a painting theme in relation with a musical theme. The paintings are by Anne Graham and music composed and played by Michael Smither.
